byline.original: By ERIC SCHMITT and KAREEM FAHIM
byline.contributor: Eric Schmitt reported from Washington, and Kareem Fahim from Tripoli, Libya.

abstract: US State Dept is sending dozens of American contractors, weapons and explosives specialists, to Libya as part of a growing $30 million program to secure Libya's conventional weapons arsenal, ransacked during the fall of the government of Col Muammar el-Qaddafi; American and other Western officials are concerned that as weapons slip from state custody they could easily be sold through black markets to other countries to fuel regional wars or arm terrorist groups.
snippet: In the rush to take the capital, rebel forces who captured military garrisons along the way often looted weapons depots and guarded them only occasionally at best.

lead_paragraph: In the rush to take the capital, rebel forces who captured military garrisons along the way often looted weapons depots and guarded them only occasionally at best.

headline.main: U.S. Sending More Contractors to Secure Libya’s Weapons Stockpile
headline.print_headline: U.S. Sending More Contractors to Secure Libya’s Weapons Stockpile
headline.seo: U.S. Sending Contractors to Secure Libya’s Weapons
